sources.title: "The Lady" (1925) director Frank Borzage with Norma Talmadge
sources.description: This gem is presented by Silent Hall of Fame.   Please visit https://silent-hall-of-fame.org/   to support our non-profit mission and the legacy of silent movie stars by making a tax deductible contribution.   FEEL FREE TO FOLLOW US ON TWITTER @SilentFilmGems     This is a short preview. You can watch the whole film here: https://silent-hall-of-fame.org/index.php/gems-for-donation   "The Lady" is a poignant drama starring Norma Talmadge. After a woman is abandoned by her husband she gives birth to a boy. Later, when a man shows up with a court order to take her baby, she is faced with heartbreaking choices. Norma Talmadge delivers one of the finest performances of her career.   Directed by                     Frank Borzage Produced by                   Norma Talmadge Film Corporation Scenario by                    Frances Marion, from the play by Martin Brown Starring                          Norma Talmadge, Wallace MacDonald, Brandon Hurst, Marc McDermott, George Hackathorne Cinematography            Tony Gaudio Distributed by                First National Pictures Release date                    February 8, 1925 Running time                 61 minutes Country                           United States Language                         Silent film, English intertitles   Copyright Disclaimer Under Section 107 of the Copyright Act 1976: "Allowance is made for "fair use" for purposes such as criticism, comment, news reporting, teaching, scholarship, and research. metadata.Plot: A young woman marries the wastrel son of a British aristocrat. Her husband, who has been disinherited by his father, loses what little money he has left gambling in casinos and then dies, leaving her penniless and with an infant son. When her former father-in-law tries to get custody of the child, she leaves him with a couple she trusts, but when she later goes to reclaim her son, she can't find the people she left him with.
metadata.Actors: Norma Talmadge, Wallace MacDonald, Brandon Hurst
